banner.text: Let's make a pixel that wanders around the lightboard, leaving a trail of light... a bit like a screensaver!

First, you need to store the position of the pixel using variables.
Open the Variables tray.
Drag the block into your code space.
Connect it to this block.

This variable will store the horizontal X position (left and right).
Change it to pixelX.

Now grab a number block for the X position.
Open the Variables tray.
Drag the block into your code space...
...and connect it to this block.

Nice. Now place the pixel in the middle of the lightboard.
Change it from 0 to 8.

Let's grab a second variable for the vertical Y position (up and down).
Open the Variables tray again.
Drag the block onto your code space.
Connect it to this block.

Great! This variable will store the Y position.
Change it to pixelY.
Now open the Variables tray.
Drag the block into your code space...
...and connect it to this block.
Change it from 0 to 5.

You're making an animation, so you'll need to use a loop.
Open the Control tray.
Drag the block into your code space.
Connect it to this block.

Let's speed up the animation!
Change it from seconds to frames.

Now let's start turning on the lights!
Open the lightboard tray.
Drag the block into your code space...
...and connect it to this block.

Do you know how to turn on specific lights, using variables?
Open this tray.
Drag the block into your code space.
Connect it to this block.

Nice work! Now let's connect your variables to the draw loop.
Open the Variables tray.
Drag the block into your code space...
...and connect it to this block.
OK! Now set the light at X variable to pixelX.
Open the Variables tray again.
Drag the block into your code space.
Connect it to this block.
That's it! Now set the light at Y variable to pixelY.
Did you see your light move to the centre of the lightboard? 8 pixels from the left and 5 from the top... just like your variables. Now let's make it move around.

It's time to change our variables.
Open the Math tray.
Now drag the block into your code space...
...and connect it to this block.
Change it to pixelX.

Wow it flew right off the lightboard ðŸ‘€!
What happens if you use random values?
Open the Math tray again.
Drag the block into your code space.
Connect it to this block.

Awesome. You only want the pixel to move small, random amounts.
Change 0 to -1.
Now change 10 to 1.
Is your pixel wobbling around? You see, -1 moves it to the left of the board, and 1 to the right. Now let's do the same to the Y axis.
Open the Math tray.
Drag the block into your code space...
...and connect it to this block.
Change it to pixelY.
Open the Math tray again.
Drag the block into your code space.
Connect it to this block.
Great! Now change it from 0 to -1.
Change 10 to 1.

Cool! It's wandering around the lightboard... try press the restart button a few times.
Now let's add some color.

We'll keep the color in a variable too.
Open the Variables tray.
Drag the block into your code space...
...and connect it to this block.
Now change it to hue
Open the Variables tray again.
And drag the block into your code space.
Connect it to this block.
Wonderful. Open the Color tray.
Drag the block into your code space...
...and connect it to this block.

We need to use hsv colors to a raindow.
Change rgb to hsv.

Now let's add your hue variable.
Open the Variables tray.
Drag the block into your code space.
Connect it to this block...
...and change it to hue.

Nice work... you've made it red! Now let's use math to create a rainbow trail ðŸŒˆ.
Open the Math tray again.
Drag the block into your code space...
...and connect it to this block.

As you increase the hue variable, the colors will transform into a rainbow.
Change it to hue.

This looks great! Hmmm... sometimes it wanders off into nowhere.
Letâ€™s use another loop to reset the position.
Open the Control tray.
Drag the block into your code space.
Connect it to this block.

Let's reset it every 3 seconds.
Change it from 1 to 3.

Now, clear the lightboard by turning the lights off.
Open this tray.
Drag the block into your code space...
..and connect it to this block.
Now open this tray...
...and drag the block into your code space.
Connect it to this block.
Nice! You can reset the variables to move your wandering pixel back to the middle of the lightboard. open the Variables tray.
Drag the block into your code space...
...and connect it to this block.
Great. Change it to pixelX.
Open the Variables tray again...
...and drag the block into your code space.
Connect it to this block.

Now, let's centre your pixel again.
Change 0 to 8.
Almost done! Open the Variables tray.
Drag the block into your code space...
...and connect it to this block.
Good work. Now change it to pixelY.
Open the Variables tray one last time.
Drag the block into your code space.
Connect it to this block.

Centre your pixel again.
Change 0 to 5.
You've just created a wandering pixel that leaves a rainbow trail, AND a second loop to restarts the lightshow automatically... That's awesome!
How long do you have to wait to get all the lights on? Can you make it go faster?
